reviewText: A Matter of Life and Death is a picture that defines the term 'classic film'. Always inventive in their efforts, The Archers - Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger - have here created yet another true cinematic masterpiece that at once is entertaining, thought-provoking and moving. And they do so with great style, taste and wit. This picture is a seamless interweaving of drama, fantasy and humor of the highest order, sprinkled throughout with profound philosophical questions.  The attention to detail is superb.  Powell and Pressburger employ an ingenuous use of three-strip Technicolor and monochrome dye-transfer photography which compliment the story perfectly - as does the excellent musical score by Allan Gray.  David Niven, Kim Hunter, Roger Livesey, Marius Goring and Raymond Massey lead a fine cast, and are quite excellent.  (Goring, who plays the foppish Conductor 71, also plays the young English composer Julian Craster in another of the Archers' extraordinary films, "The Red Shoes" - portrayals which are testaments to fine acting.)Right from the opening credit, when the archer's bull's-eye fades into Technicolor after the arrow finds its mark, the viewer is in for a grand cinematic treat! A picture that only improves with repeated viewings, A Matter of Life and Death deserves to be as well-known as any film the reader can think of - and more so than many which are.At long last, Region 1 is about to have this cinematic gem available on DVD - well, at least those fortunate to be North of the 49th Parallel (another fine Archers film).
summary: A True  Classic and A Gem of the Cinema

reviewText: For people who loved "Heaven Can Wait," here's a more subtle take on the same idea.David Niven is a pilot flying a mission near the end of World War II. His plane is hit, his parachute torn up and his aircraft in flames. Before jumping to his death, he makes contact with June, a young American radio operator, and utters some typically breezy, British "stiff upper lip" sentiments. The two fall in love over the radio -- then he jumps. But he doesn't die. The angel who is supposed to escort him to heaven messes up and Niven lands on a beach, just as June is trundling by on her bike.So now the issue becomes, will Niven be allowed to live?Visually, the movie is striking with the scenes down here on earth in color and those in the afterlife in black and white. The doors of heaven are bursting with young men killed in the war (all white and no Jewish victims of the Holocaust I note). There is also a massive moving stairway -- a kind of 1940s Jacob's Ladder leading to the afterlife. The reception area in heaven seems to be staffed exclusively by British women clerks. It seems that heaven is just an extension of England, with the old class system firmly in place.A trial takes place at which Niven's fate is decided. The prosecutor is the first man to die in the American revolution. The defense lawyer is a brilliant neurologist who has been treating Niven on earth and conveniently gets himself killed in a motorbike accident so that he can participate in this tribunal in the afterlife. The trial itself is utterly bizarre -- it turns into a debate about the merits of the American and British civilizations. Considering the two countries had just joined forced to defeat Nazism when this movie was made, it's surprising to see so much bad feeling expressed on both sides.I was moderately entertained by this movie but disagree with those who hail it as some kind of masterpiece. It's the product of its time, with some interesting imagery and an amusing premise -- but no masterpiece.
summary: Interesting take on the power of love (and U.S.-British relations)

reviewText: The Film has an all star cast. You can tell from the quality and pacing that this is a Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger movie. It was made after WWII."This is a story of two Worlds, The one we know and another which exists only in the mind of a young airman whose life & imagination have been violently shaped by war"A British wartime aviator, Peter Carter (David Niven), jumps from a burning plain without a parachute. He seems to have avoided death by accident. They want him back. Too late as he has fell in love with June (Kim Hunter), an American radio operator that was concerned about his last minutes, and demands a trial.We see ht problem and solution but will he win? We get to watch and maybe do a little kibitzing on the side. As the trial unfolds we get the feel that this trial is bigger than just two people in love."Love" by Scott, Sir Walter, 1771-1832"In peace, Love tunes the shepherd's reed;In war, he mounts the warrior's steed;In halls, in gay attire is seen;In hamlets, dances on the green.Love rules the court, the camp, the grove,And men below and saints above;For love is heaven, and heaven is love."-------------------Be sure to get the DVD with the voice over commentary.

reviewText: It takes awhile for this movie to get ahold of you.  It has some characteristics -- shifting between B&W; and technicolor scenes, some intense monologues that run too fast to digest, screens full of astronomy to represent eternity, tableaux of gatherings in heaven, some frozen scenes -- that come across as "artsy" at first.Minute by minute, though, the movie pulls you in -- from the "love at first voice" between RAF pilot David Niven and American WAC tower controller Kim Hunter, through Niven's death, to a heavenly trial that will decide whether the two have a life together, to a bracing finish.  Along the way, there are some nice surprises -- scenes that anticipate a more diverse America and, using Indian Army characters, a world of equal peoples.As Niven and Hunter in turn step off and on the stairway that leads to death and eternity, my take is that the script drew from concepts of love in at least three metaphors -- love between man and woman, Christ's sacrificing love for humankind, and love of country.  One reason the film stays with you is that it provides a lot to think about.Though it showed on the big screen after the end of the war, the film was conceived when there were strains in the alliance between Britain and America.  It began, perhaps, as a "morale" film.  Michael Powell and Emerich Pressburger -- who together wrote, produced, and directed the film -- delivered much more.-30-
summary: Three kinds of love -- quite the film!

reviewText: Today, on May 2, 1945, the celestial Chief Recorder is a bit out of sorts. She's done the tally and has come up with an invoice of 91,716 incoming souls, and yet only 91,715 have been confirmed as arrived. The blame rests on that blasted English fog, of which pea-soup consistency was so impenetrable that Conductor 71 (Marius Goring) utterly failed to see and collect his target.The oversight is 27-year-old Peter D. Carter (David Niven), R.A.F. captain of a plummeting bomber plane. Peter's crew had already bailed out on his orders. His aircraft ablaze and the undercarriage absent, Peter will presently bail out himself, never mind that he has no working parachute. What's keeping him onboard is his radio conversation with June (Kim Hunter), an American radio operator based in England. The assumption is that, when lives are imperiled, time is better passed than indulging in flirtatious dialogue. Except that when you've given up the ghost, when you've resigned yourself to death, an interval this sweet is savored all the more. Moments before his fatal plunge over the foggy English Channel, tethered to a radio frequency, Peter and June fall in love.Even as the celestial offices note Peter Carter's absence, he washes up on English shore, confoundingly alive and not too far from where June is taking her stroll on the beach. And when the flamboyant Conductor 71 finally manifests to collect his soul, Peter's resignation to death has very much elapsed and now Conductor 71 has a fight on his hands.A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH, first released in the UK in 1946, is British fantasy at its most romantic. It's another in a line of films of which premise involves someone attempting to cheat death. It's masterfully directed and innovatively staged. Yanks may know it by its alternate (and, in my opinion, weaker) title of STAIRWAY TO HEAVEN. There's an audacity and creativity in its vision, in its modernist presentation of the heavenly set pieces, in its evocation of an afterlife that is sterile and bureaucratic and yet rife with sly levity (I love that, in Heaven, a Coke machine awaits incoming Yanks). For its time, the special effects are top notch. In a swerve on THE WIZARD OF OZ, the afterlife is presented in black and white and Earth in lush Technicolor. It unequivocally informs you of Peter's preference. It compels Conductor 71 to indulge in a wry moment of meta-commentary.It's a phenomenal cast, with Niven and Hunter terrific as the star-crossed lovers. When the celestial court grants Peter's appeal for a hearing and his case is tried in a tribunal, Raymond Massey sneers his way in as the prosecuting counsel, an American who harbors a mighty grudge against the British for making him the first casualty of the American Revolutionary War. His distaste for the British is palpable and ominous. And yet most of the scene-stealing goes to Roger Livesey who breathes magnificent life into his character of Dr. Reeves, the big-hearted neurologist enamoured of his camera obscura and solicitous of his friends and patients. Meanwhile, Marius Goring as Conductor 71 is wonderfully amusing and marvelously French and provides a welcome subversive presence. If you're living on supernaturally borrowed time, get you a dashing neurologist and a fop from the French Revolution to champion your cause. Daniel Webster can go lump it.By the way, if you want a Region 1 DVD of this film, the only one that seems to be presently available is in this 2-disc set:The Films of Michael Powell: A Matter of Life and Death (Stairway to Heaven) / Age of Consent.
summary: "One is starved for Technicolor up there."

reviewText: The Archers, Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, would begin their films with their own brief credit sequence of an arrow shooting a target: however close the arrow hit the center indicated how well they thought they had succeeded with the particular film. In this incredibly influential 1946 fantasy, one of their most elaborate and fantastic productions (which is really saying something), they thought they had hit the bullseye, and most critics have agreed: recently, this was voted the second best British film ever (after GET CARTER) by a body of UK film critics. But despite its inventiveness and some marvelous performances, it's actually one of their clunkier films, and is marred by one of its central performances and by some very twee dialogue about Anglo-American relations in its celebrated celestial courtroom scene.It starts magnificently, with fighter pilot David Niven radioing what he assumes will be his last words to an American servicewoman (Kim Hunter) as his otherwise abandoned plane spirals out of control to its assured fiery doom. Niven jumps out without a parachute to what he hopes will be a faster and less painful death, but he somehow miraculously survives, meets Hunter, and falls in love. But he discovers that his survival was unplanned in a kind of celestial clearing house when the shade of an aristocrat beheaded in the French Revolution (Marius Goring) is sent down to insist he returns: things then become more or less like a happier reworking of THE DEVIL AND DANIEL WEBSTER. This is probably Niven's finest performance, and he is well matched by his neurologist, and eventual defending attorney in the otherworld, Roger Livesey, one of the Archers' favorite performers and quite possibly the most amiable and pleasing British actor of the entire period. As fond of the Archers were of Livesey, however, they also were inexplicably enamored with one of the ghastliest actors of the same period, Marius Goring, whose over-the-top foppishness and unconvincing accent made me want to head for the hills (fortunately, Goring's performance becomes less visible as the film proceeds). The film was made (like the Archers' preceding and less well-known, though superior, film A CANTERBURY TALE) expressly to encourage Anglo-American relations, but the impossibly arch dialogue when Livesey has to defend Niven in the court of the next world from an anti-British prosecuting attorney (Raymond Massey) is too much to take. The Archers may be more inventive here in their camerawork as in any of their great films of the Forties, and though a few are somewhat unappetizing (such as a bizarre POV shot of Niven on an operating table closing his eyes, so that huge fringed false eyelids shot through with red veins close over it) they move so incredibly quickly it's hard to be that bothered, and other sequences (including a table-tennis match frozen in time and a great extended sequence with a camera obscura) are as fine and startling as anything Powell and Pressburger have ever done.

reviewText: David Niven stars as Peter, a squadron leader during World War II whose plane is about to crash after being hit by the enemy. All of his crew are dead. The radio controller from the airbase is a young American, June, who tries to persuade Peter to bail out before it is too late. Peter intends to do that but unfortunately he has no parachute. Still, deciding it's a better way to die, he jumps.No one is more surprised than him when he awakes on a beach having been washed ashore close to his airbase. He meets June and it's love at first sight. However, Peter wasn't supposed to survive the crash but the `angel' sent to meet him got lost in the fog and missed the `appointment'. Now this being wants Peter to give up life and return with him to heaven. Peter refuses on the basis of his love for June and decides to appeal against his fate, something that hasn't been seen before, and a trial in Heaven follows.In a reversal from most films of this type, the scenes in Heaven are shot in black and white whilst the Earthly scenes are shot in wonderfully vivid colour. This is a film that has stood the test of time and is as good to watch today as it has ever been, proof that special effects and a frenetic pace do not beat a good, well acted story. The DVD has very little in the way of extras (region 2 version) but there are subtitles for the hard of hearing and a brief interview with the main cameraman. Wonderful movie.

reviewText: The Bottom Line:A Matter of Life and Death/Stairway to Heaven is an ambitious and successful film about a British pilot who lands alive when he should have died (a clerical error in Heaven) and must argue for continuing his life in front of a massive celestial court; enjoyable and interesting, the movie dates itself a little with its 1946 take on US-UK relations but emerges as a fine fantasy with inspired photography and innovative direction.3.5/4

reviewText: I first saw this as part of a season of "wartime" films on BBC2, compared by Michael Palin who did a quite wonderful introduction, explaining gems such as the "freeze frame" scenes where The Conductor freezes time to speak to David Niven were filed live action with (for example) the ping pong ball on a string and apparently Roger Livesey was always trying to make the cast laugh during these scenes, or how filming was delayed because sufficient stocks of Technicolor film were not available (which lead to the inclusion of the black and white scenes - how imaginative). Stars such as Dicky Attenborough and Bonor Colleano appear in cameos and the overall effect is wonderful, in fact it is perfect. We don't really know if David Niven is imagining the whole thing or not, which is part of the delicious-ness of the film. I had to wonder at the propaganda element of the film, as I thought it seemed to highlight the divisions extant at the time, and particularly refers to British colonialism. (Spoiler warning!)Its a great moment when Abraham Farlon accuses Roger Livesey of being able to select a jury that was unpredudicial towards an English defendant and Livesey replies "I choose a Jury of Americans!" The new jury of course are naturalised citizens from countries with "prejudices" against the English (Irish/French/Russian/Boer/Indian etc. Livesey shrugs his shoulders with a wry smile. Its still a powerful message today and one that must have been quite controversial at the time I imagine. There are so many moments like that in the film, romantic, insightful, moving, and although the overall love story is "cheesy", its done both well, and tongue in cheek, and so the effect is never cloying and always touching. You would think it might be hard to 5 star a film with no surprises, you can see the plot unfolding a country mile away but because it is done so brilliantly, and so well cast, you will never forget it. In those lists of the "best films ever" which always feature "Its a wonderful Life" and "Battleship Potemkin", "A Matter of Life and Death" is always up there, and quite rightly too, its a masterpiece and if I were to be offered the chance to watch one film before I died, it would be this one.(Oh, and "Bothams Ashes", but that's not a film!)
summary: A Matter of Life and Death? Its more important than that!
Title: N/A

reviewText: David Niven stars in 1946 British classic film, A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH (US release originally titled STAIRWAY TO HEAVEN), where he plays a British RAF pilot, Peter D. Carter, who happens to fall in love with Kim Hunter (June), an American WAC, during the last battle of the European theater of World War II.  Carter's plane is about to go down, and June is speaking to him over the radio hoping to keep his spirits up despite the imminent - death.  However, Carter tests Heaven despite the fact that has his name on its roster.Although the title may sound grim, A MATTER OF LIFE OF DEATH is not at all presented with that in mind.  The film has a tongue-in-cheek quality with plenty of humor and satire.  Indeed, there are displays of stereotypes and clash of cultures between the British and Americans that have existed since the British landing in the New World and the proceeding wars that occurred thereafter, but Directors Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger subtly and intelligently show examples of each respective group's culture through radio broadcasts, one has the voice of Winston Churchill and the other has Jazz blaring through the speakers, but are both counterbalanced with positive paradigms.The interesting aspect of the film that interconnects history, literature, and philosophy and science.  Before the war, Peter Carter studied at Oxford and specialized in European history.  How fitting because his guide to heaven is the humorous character, Conductor 71 (Marius Goring), who may have been Voltaire, French literary critic and Philosopher known for his historical novel, CANDIDE, and imbibes the philosophical and scientific references to the film with his succint mention of the time and space continuum.  In addition, when Carter is put on trial, the prosecuting counsel is Abraham Farlan (Raymond Massey), an officer in the Revolutionary War, who was hit by a British bullet during the battle at Lexington and Concord in 1775.Overall, A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH speaks of the premise that love conquers all.  Although somewhat romanticized and fictional, the film uses that stance with references to the historical past, and how the past may effect critical events in the present.  In the case of Peter and June, the verdict was in their favor.  So, for an enlightening and thought-provoking film with a little reference to history, this is the one to watch.

reviewText: This is a great movie about finding love just before you are about to die and being given a chance to live and hold onto that love and to be with them.  A note about my DVD as it is Region 2 and I play it on my Region Free DVD Player in the United States.  The PAL system used Europe and other parts of the world has a 4% speed increase over the NTSC system used in the United States and other parts of this region due to the way it is configured without going into all of the details here.  This means that this movie is actually 104 minutes but played back at the 4% speed increase of the PAL system the movie runs 100 minutes.  Nothing is cut just speeded up a little bit which is not noticeable and I did not see a difference when I watched it.  I just wanted to mention the PAL vs. NTSC movie time differences as you may think you are getting an edited version of the movie but you are not, just a slightly speeded up version.  If you want to check this out just go to IMDb which will show the correct running times as filmed and then check your PAL version and take 4% off the original running time and you will see the running time for the PAL system which is probably just a minute or few minutes difference.  I hope this helps clarify to some of you who may think you are not getting the whole movie but you are just speeded up by 4% which you should not notice any difference in the picture or sound.

reviewText: For about a decade, beginning in the late 1930s and extending into the late 1940s, Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger crafted a number of brilliant and beautiful fantasy films, from THE THIEF OF BAGHDAD to THE LIFE AND DEATH OF COLONEL BLIMP to I KNOW WHERE I AM GOING to THE RED SHOES. But of all of these films, my personal favorite is the amazing fantasy about the meaning of love and death A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATHSeveral reviewers seem to be mildly confused about the country of origin of these films, including the film here. These were not Hollywood films. Powell and Pressburger formed their own production company, dubbed the Archers, and subsequently used other studios as distributors. One of the reasons that I am stressing this is the fact that I do not believe that British cinema from the forties and fifties has received its proper respect. There were a large number of superb filmmakers working in Great Britain during that time, often making films that were more striking and imaginative than were being produced in Hollywood.The casting of this film is remarkable. David Niven, who actually appeared in far fewer first rate films than one might expect, given his celebrity status, is marvelous. Along with his turns in BACHELOR MOTHER and RAFFLES, this is easily my favorite David Niven film. One reason that some reviewers may be under the impression that the film was made in Hollywood was the presence of Kim Hunter and Raymond in the film. This was one of Kim Hunter's first significant roles, playing the part of a young American woman who falls in love with a man who should have died. Raymond Massey, however, was no stranger to British film, having starred in the first great British Sci-fi film, THINGS TO COME, as well as other productions such as THE SCARLET PIMPERNEL. But for me the delight of the film is seeing Roger Livesey, who appeared in many of The Archers best films, in another role.Visually, this is a stunning film. The gigantic staircase upon which Niven and Marius Goring sit while trying to decide who would defend Niven in his appeal to heaven for a reconsideration of his death. And several of the scenes in heaven are remarkably striking.This is one of those films that even casual fans of movies cannot afford to miss.
summary: Moving, funny, beautiful, and profound all at once

reviewText: "Stairway to Heaven" is one of those movies you're more likely to catch if you've taken one of those movie-criticism classes in college than something you'd decide to watch for pure fun - which is a shame.  This garish, almost reckless romantic, comedy-drama is light-years ahead of the stuff Hollywood's been drowning us in.THE PLOT: Peter, an RAF pilot, is as good as dead when he "meets" June.  His airplane stricken, and at a loss for a good parachute, Peter knows his end is near. Stoic in the face of doom, he nevertheless reaches out for whatever link there is to our world - and it's the voice of June that holds him down.  When Peter unexpectedly "survives" his ordeal, he tracks down the lovely (and American) voice that kept him from the next world, and falls in love with its owner.  Ahh, but Peter didn't really survive - he's actually trapped between Earth and Heaven, suited it seems for neither.  Among those in heaven, Peter is accused of falling in love selfishly to keep a toehold on Earth; of course everybody on Earth ridicules Peter's fantasies of being prosecuted in the heavens.  Peter's guide is "Conductor 71" (Marius Goring - famous for "The Red Shoes", Powell & Pressburg's other great contribution to the canon of college-movie classes).  The Conductor is a great character - a wraith who last lived as a romantic French during the revolutionary era,  Like Peter, the Conductor is also a romantic, and he lost his head proving it.  (Now as a sort of celestial bureaucrat, he gets the best lines of the movie.)  However, Heaven doesn't run on love, it runs on rules - and it puts Peter on trial for his life.  When the trial begins, Peter realizes that the odds are stacked against him - the workings of the machine of life and death are not watched by the angels, but by the dead themselves, dispassionate spirits who loved and lost and are not predisposed to be as forgiving to others.  His chief prosecutor is a fiery New Englander killed by a British bullet during the American Revolutionary war and played (just to let Peter know that Heaven means business) by Ray Massey."Stairway" meanders a bit in the "trial" stage, but the film never loses its power to alternate between touching, menacing and funny.  Meant to foster anglo-yankee relations, the film is replete with reminders of the massive global conflict that had kept the real Conductors busy since 1939.  Heaven, we see, is populated by ranks of the dead - lines of nurses, doctors, soldiers, officers, all in neat rows.  There is a sense that death is a new experience to most of Heaven's inhabitants, and they're not quite up to speed.  At the same time, the film warns the rest of us who seem to have forgotten how to live.  (The story makes such a great case for *not* letting Peter off the hook, that we're almost inclined to agree with Ray Massey's character.)  The story's message then is that the world has become far to accustomed to the rules of dying to break them for the sake of life and love.  Pressburger & Powell probably broke a few rules themselves.  "They're starved for Technicolor up there", the 18th century Conductor says at an early point.  The scenes of heaven are filmed in BW in contrast to those on Earth, yet the line about Technicolor is only one of the more noteworthy moments of genius.  One of Pressburger or Powell (don't know who exactly) insisted on the line and, once hearing Goring utter it on-screen, realized that there was nothing they couldn't do.  In short, the flick is something akin to a miracle.

reviewText: I know a lot of my friends are probably going to be sick of me saying this - I'm not used to old "classic" movies, but I have to say I really enjoyed this one. Filmmakers Michael Powell and Emric Pressburger were told by the Ministry of Information to make a movie that would foster a British/US alliance after the War and establish the need for goodwill between the 2 nations, and they came up with this - a truly extraordinary fantasy/romance. A pilot, Peter Carter (David Niven) must justify his exsistance to a heavenly panel because he has made the mistake of falling for an American girl (Kim Hunter) when he really should have been dead after falling out of his plane without a parachute. Interestingly, the "heaven" sequences are black and white, while the "earth" sequences are in Technicolor.The film is very touching and also very funny in the way it lampoons national stereotypes as the panel debates Niven's fate - the prosecution are led by a man from the 18th Century called Abraham Farlan (Raymond Massey), who presents "The sound of England in 1945" as boring cricket on the radio, but "The sound of America in 1945" as hip swing-band jazz.Jack Cardiff's cinematography mixes black and white and colour, and I also liked the way the film played with time lapses and would freeze the action, something normally associated with science fiction rather than a romance.I'm very pleased I saw this - what a superb film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***I simply cannot understand why so many people consider 'A Matter of Life and Death' (aka Stairway to Heaven) a cinematic masterpiece. I mean there are some who have the audacity to compare this light weight, dated fantasy-comedy to the great 'It's a Wonderful Life'. Seriously, do you really feel that a one-dimensional character such as Peter Carter can be compared to the fascinating and multi-dimensional George Bailey? Compare how artfully the relationship between George and Mary develops in 'It's a Wonderful Life' to the superficiality of the immediate bond between Peter and June in 'Life and Death'. After the mistake in the afterlife allows Peter to survive the fall from his stricken aircraft, we're treated to the ridiculous coincidence of Peter landing on the beach right next to where June lives and wouldn't you know it, he runs in to her right away. Yes, I know this is a fantasy, but the way they just fall in love right on the spot is not only way over the top but also suggests a severe lack of character development in the screen writing department.After the intriguing introduction in which an emissary (Marius Goring's 'Conductor 71') is sent down to earth to convince Peter Carter to return to the afterlife following a bureaucratic snafu, we're treated to the further interesting complication of Peter's refusal to leave earth coupled with an offer to appeal the order of return in front of a heavenly tribunal. But before we arrive at the climax, the big trial scene, there's a long stretch in the middle of the movie where little happens. I'm referring to all those repetitious scenes where June's neurologist pal, Dr. Reeves, is attending to Peter, attempting to analyze the root of his 'hallucinations'. Instead of employing non-invasive psychotherapeutic techniques, Reeves eventually puts Peter at risk by concluding that his hallucinations are due to a prior brain injury and orders immediate surgery. Kim Hunter as June has little to do except make like a statute every time Conductor 71 comes down to earth (you'll notice that Hunter has a great deal of difficulty standing still during all those freeze frame scenes).It also seemed a bit coincidental, that Dr. Reeves, trained as a neurologist, suddenly morphs into a most articulate defense attorney following his awkward death after he's hit by an ambulance while driving his motorcycle.'Life and Death' was supposedly written to mend British-American relations, severely strained during the war. The Brits apparently felt the Americans should have entered the war earlier and never could appreciate the privations the civilian population suffered due to bombing raids and rationing. Despite the replacement of the 'anti-British' jury with an All-American group who votes to extend Peter's time on earth, Reeves and Abraham Farlan (Raymond Massey's first American victim of the Revolutionary War) exchange some rather nasty comments regarding each other country's weak points. Farlan's diatribe is basically the highlight of the trial scene and because of that, the Americans come off much as more mean-spirited than their British counterparts. Despite their attempt to mend Anglo-American relations, to my mind Director Powell and his co-writer, did more to harm such relations than help them. In the end, Peter Carter gets the American girl and not the other way around.Despite all the clever cinematography by master cinematographer Jack Cardiff, 'Life and Death' turns into a nice little piece of agitprop in its Third Act, unable to decide whether it's pro or anti-American. As for the fantasy element of the film, Peter's restoration is utterly predictable as the Massey straw man fires softballs inside the feel-good arena.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This 60-year-old fantasy about a British pilot who escapes death through no fault of his own, but who becomes the object of, for want of a better term, an angel hunt to get him to give up his life as scheduled, is intelligent and literate, humorous and thought-provoking. Niven falls in love with Kim Hunter, and she with him, which provides the pilot with an argument that he should be allowed to remain on earth and in the flesh. Who prosecutes him, who defends him, who judges him forms the core of the fantasy portion of the film. While the special effects are dated, as is some of the rhetoric, overall, this one satisfies.

reviewText: I adore this movie. Even despite its heavy toned moralizing, it is a colorful, off balance, headturner of a film.So where's this DVD? I got a notification from amazon about its release around a year and a half ago. And still it sits in limbo. I've got my twenty dollars in hand, just itching to plunk it down for this pristine ghostly romance.Somebody, somewhere...Get on the ball!
